<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/08/twitter-permanently-suspends-trumps-account?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Twitter Does a 280 on Trump's Account
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Trump's Twitter Account" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjUwL3RydW1wX3NfdHdpdHRlcl9hY2NvdW50LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>@realDonaldTrump</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A defining feature of the rise of Donald Trump’s political career and his presidency has been his Twitter account, which he’s used to fight trade wars, spread conspiracy theories, attack the media, and cheer on the stock market. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As of last night, Trump’s Twitter account is no more. The company announced it was <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/22603606.0/aHR0cHM6Ly9ibG9nLnR3aXR0ZXIuY29tL2VuX3VzL3RvcGljcy9jb21wYW55LzIwMjAvc3VzcGVuc2lvbi5odG1sP3V0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759Bd6f51d31?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">permanently suspending</a> @realDonaldTrump “due to the risk of further incitement of violence.”  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><em>Further </em></span><span>violence beyond what happened at the Capitol this Wednesday? Seems that way. In its explanation for suspending Trump's account, Twitter mentioned that "plans for future armed protests have already begun proliferating on and off-Twitter, including a proposed secondary attack on the US Capitol and state capitol buildings on January 17, 2021." </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">During Trump's presidency, Twitter had relaxed some of its policies for his account under its “public interest framework,” which contends that tweets from world leaders are too important to be subject to rules the rest of its users must follow. However, Trump's role in inciting the violence at the Capitol this week apparently crossed a line. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">That’s not the end of the story</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Later Friday night, the president switched over to the government-owned @POTUS account to <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/08/trump-tweets-from-potus-handle-account-says-looking-at-the-possibilities-of-building-out-our-own-platform.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">post a statement</a> railing against Twitter and Section 230, legislation that grants social media companies immunity from content their users post. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“We have been negotiating with various other sites, and will have a big announcement soon, while we also look at the possibilities of building out our own platform in the near future,” Trump tweeted.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Twitter removed the tweets soon after they were posted.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>In the past few days, social media platforms have taken <a href="https://www.axios.com/platforms-social-media-ban-restrict-trump-d9e44f3c-8366-4ba9-a8a1-7f3114f920f1.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unprecedented action</a> to mute the president of the U.S. in the wake of the violence in D.C. Facebook/Instagram banned Trump’s account for at least two weeks, Snapchat disabled his account, and Twitch did the same. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Also yesterday, Google </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/apple-threatens-to-ban-parler-from-app-store-11610148297?mod=article_inline&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pulled</a></span><span> the free speech-focused social media app Parler from the Google Play store, saying that posting on the app “seeks to incite ongoing violence in the U.S.” Apple may soon follow up with a similar ban. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The final tweet from @realDonaldTrump, for posterity:</strong> “To all those who have asked, I will not be going to the Inauguration on January 20th.” </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/08/us-economy-loses-140000-jobs-close-worst-year-since-1939?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Job Market Gets Worse Before It Gets Better
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Job illustration" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQ1L2pvYl9pbGx1c3RyYXRpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The U.S. economy <a href="https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-economy-ad4cb9fe70653c56ac6253aaab210f21?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shed 140,000 jobs</a> in December, wrapping up the worst year for job losses since 1939. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The unemployment rate held steady at 6.7%, although that’s the first time it hasn’t dropped month-over-month since April. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backdrop: </strong>As Covid-19 case numbers rose, state and local governments reimplemented restrictions on businesses to try to re-flatten the curve and keep healthcare systems from being overrun. And colder weather kept many of us from dining outdoors—beef snowganoff just doesn’t have the same kick. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But help is on the way </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last month, Congress passed a $900 billion stimulus package that included direct payments, added unemployment benefits, and <a href="https://www.axios.com/ppp-small-business-loan-program-restart-81226b0b-3b79-4f10-85d2-a02b31733e81.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">another round</a> of the small business-focused Paycheck Protection Program. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, you don’t have to be Ned Flanders to pluck optimistic signs in the December jobs report. As the NYT’s Neil Irwin <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/08/upshot/jobs-report-economy-analysis.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">points out</a>, the biggest job losses (498,000) were in the leisure and hospitality industries, the sectors most affected by winter lockdowns and the ones most likely to regain jobs once warmer weather/the vaccine hits. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Other industries less sensitive to Covid, such as manufacturing and construction, continued to chug along and add jobs last month. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Coming into 2020, the job market was the hottest it had ever been. There’s reason to think we could return to those heights once the virus has been vanquished.  </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
STREAMING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/08/streaming-service-roku-buys-rights-quibis-catalog-shows?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Quibi Is Kinda Sorta Back
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Obi Wan Kenobi saying " Now that's a name I haven't heard in a long time"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQ3L3F1aWJpX21lbWUuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Toby Howell</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Streaming giant Roku turned the Resurrection Stone three times, but instead of getting a short convo with Sirius Black and Lily Potter, it <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/8/22220426/quibi-roku-channel-acquisition-content?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">brought back</a> short-form video app Quibi. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Roku purchased the rights to Quibi’s content library of around 75 shows and documentaries, featuring A-List stars like Idris Elba, Kevin Hart, Anna Kendrick, and Chrissy Teigen. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">It was an even better deal than Wendy’s 4-for-4 menu:</strong></span><span> Roku paid </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/roku-acquires-rights-to-quibi-s-content-11610116056?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">well under $100 million</a></span><span> for Quibi’s entire catalog, per the WSJ. Compare that to the nearly $2 billion Quibi raised in its short existence before closing shop this past October, just six months after its hyped April debut. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Roku, which now owns the exclusive rights to Quibi’s shows, will offer the content <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/roku-deal-will-stream-quibi-shows-free-with-ads-on-roku-channel/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">for free</a> to users through an ad-supported model on the Roku Channel. It’s an important step for the platform, given that the majority of its catalog consists of movies and shows that it doesn’t own. </p>

HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/08/biden-administration-plans-release-almost-available-vaccine-doses-break-trump-plan?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Biden Calls an Audible on Vaccine Rollout
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">President-elect Joe Biden’s transition team said it <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/08/politics/biden-vaccine-strategy/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">plans to release</a> almost all Covid-19 vaccine doses available in order to inject a little hare into what has been a tortoise-y immunization campaign. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">...We didn’t do that already? </strong>Nope. Since both of the vaccines approved by the FDA require <em>two</em> doses spaced a few weeks apart, the current administration has been holding back doses to ensure there’s plenty of supply to jab people a second time—and right on schedule.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Many medical experts support the current approach, arguing it’s dangerous to mess with the planned vaccine rollout. After all, what if second doses aren’t available when they’re needed?  </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Others, including former FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb, <a href="https://twitter.com/ScottGottliebMD/status/1347570040552435714?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">advocate</a> prioritizing the first dose in a campaign informally called “First Doses First” (FDF). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2021/01/first-doses-first-and-herd-immunity.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The simplest argument</a></span><span> in favor of FDF, writes economist Alex Tabarrok, is that “two vaccinated people confers more immunity than one double vaccinated person.”  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Biden’s betting that a) we can give more people first shots <em>now</em>, and while that happens b) manufacturers can ramp up production to provide enough second doses when they’re needed.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
DESIGN
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/08/lots-brands-releasing-redesigned-logos?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Out With the Old, In With the New
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Old and new logos for GM, KIA, and the CIA" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQ2L2xvZ29zLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Toby Howell</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As we leave 2020 in the rearview mirror, many companies are doing the equivalent of getting curtain bangs: redesigning their corporate logos.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">A look at the new faces</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Kia: </strong>In the most extra logo launch of 2021, Kia debuted its updated look using <a href="https://youtu.be/s61_IsjqLzc?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">303 pyrodrones</a> and a massive fireworks display over South Korea. Early reviews are not great, Bob. MotorTrend wrote that it “resembles a futuristic inkblot test,” and we’re inclined to agree. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">GM:</strong> In another vehicular facelift, GM <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-08/gm-changes-corporate-logo-to-plug-its-electric-vehicle-strategy?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">changed its corporate logo</a> for the first time in 56 years yesterday to highlight its electric vehicle strategy. How does the new logo do that, exactly? If you look closely, the lowercase “m” is supposed to resemble an electric plug. Key words: supposed to. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">CIA:</strong> The Central Intelligence Agency’s full brand redesign is definitely the most controversial of the trio. “If I didn’t read the copy, I wouldn’t know if this was for a direct-to-consumer designer toothbrush or an organization that’s been accused of destabilizing governments worldwide,” freelance Creative Director Eric Hu <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/08/style/cia-rebrand.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told</a> the NYT. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Marketing Brew writer Phoebe Bain points out there is a method to the madness. “Lots of brands are opting for brighter and flatter logos in a move away from bold, chunky graphics.” Why? “Flatter logos look better on digital screens,” she explained.</p>

<img alt="FAANG meme" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQ5L2ZhYW5nX21lbWUucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Tesla stock continued to defy gravity yesterday, passing Facebook in market capitalization to become the fifth-most valuable company on Wall Street. It's now worth more than $800 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">More Facebook shade: </strong>Cameron Winklevoss, who along with his twin brother is famous for 1) suing Mark Zuckerberg over the idea for Facebook and 2) being a bitcoin billionaire, <a href="https://twitter.com/cameron/status/1347553042678358018?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tweeted</a> that bitcoin's market cap had also passed that of Facebook's. "Makes sense that a money network would be more valuable than a social network."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>

</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Resolutions are easier to uphold with comfy foot puppies. </strong>While<strong style="color:#000"> </strong><a href="https://bombas.com/pages/5-resolutions-bombas-socks-can-help-with?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=scontent&utm_campaign=cf_acq-bt_core-cp_sock-ca_core&utm_term=resolutions" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bombas</a> can’t make your New Year’s resolutions easier, their special performance-tech socks CAN make sure your feet are <strong style="color:#000">outrageously comfortable</strong> while you’re following through on them. style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nTwitter Does a 280 on Trump's Account\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Trump's Twitter Account\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e@realDonaldTrump\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA defining feature of the rise of Donald Trump’s political career and his presidency has been his Twitter account, which he’s used to fight trade wars, spread conspiracy theories, attack the media, and cheer on the stock market. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs of last night, Trump’s Twitter account is no more. The company announced it was \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/22603606.0/aHR0cHM6Ly9ibG9nLnR3aXR0ZXIuY29tL2VuX3VzL3RvcGljcy9jb21wYW55LzIwMjAvc3VzcGVuc2lvbi5odG1sP3V0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759Bd6f51d31?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epermanently suspending\u003c/a\u003e @realDonaldTrump “due to the risk of further incitement of violence.”  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eFurther \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eviolence beyond what happened at the Capitol this Wednesday? Seems that way. In its explanation for suspending Trump's account, Twitter mentioned that \"plans for future armed protests have already begun proliferating on and off-Twitter, including a proposed secondary attack on the US Capitol and state capitol buildings on January 17, 2021.\" \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDuring Trump's presidency, Twitter had relaxed some of its policies for his account under its “public interest framework,” which contends that tweets from world leaders are too important to be subject to rules the rest of its users must follow. However, Trump's role in inciting the violence at the Capitol this week apparently crossed a line. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThat’s not the end of the story\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLater Friday night, the president switched over to the government-owned @POTUS account to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/08/trump-tweets-from-potus-handle-account-says-looking-at-the-possibilities-of-building-out-our-own-platform.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epost a statement\u003c/a\u003e railing against Twitter and Section 230, legislation that grants social media companies immunity from content their users post. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“We have been negotiating with various other sites, and will have a big announcement soon, while we also look at the possibilities of building out our own platform in the near future,” Trump tweeted.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTwitter removed the tweets soon after they were posted.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eIn the past few days, social media platforms have taken \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/platforms-social-media-ban-restrict-trump-d9e44f3c-8366-4ba9-a8a1-7f3114f920f1.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunprecedented action\u003c/a\u003e to mute the president of the U.S. in the wake of the violence in D.C. Facebook/Instagram banned Trump’s account for at least two weeks, Snapchat disabled his account, and Twitch did the same. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAlso yesterday, Google \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/apple-threatens-to-ban-parler-from-app-store-11610148297?mod=article_inline\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epulled\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the free speech-focused social media app Parler from the Google Play store, saying that posting on the app “seeks to incite ongoing violence in the U.S.” Apple may soon follow up with a similar ban. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe final tweet from @realDonaldTrump, for posterity:\u003c/strong\u003e “To all those who have asked, I will not be going to the Inauguration on January 20th.” \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshed 140,000 jobs\u003c/a\u003e in December, wrapping up the worst year for job losses since 1939. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe unemployment rate held steady at 6.7%, although that’s the first time it hasn’t dropped month-over-month since April. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backdrop: \u003c/strong\u003eAs Covid-19 case numbers rose, state and local governments reimplemented restrictions on businesses to try to re-flatten the curve and keep healthcare systems from being overrun. And colder weather kept many of us from dining outdoors—beef snowganoff just doesn’t have the same kick. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut help is on the way \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast month, Congress passed a $900 billion stimulus package that included direct payments, added unemployment benefits, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/ppp-small-business-loan-program-restart-81226b0b-3b79-4f10-85d2-a02b31733e81.html?utm_campaign=organic\u0026utm_medium=socialshare\u0026utm_source=twitter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanother round\u003c/a\u003e of the small business-focused Paycheck Protection Program. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, you don’t have to be Ned Flanders to pluck optimistic signs in the December jobs report. As the NYT’s Neil Irwin \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/08/upshot/jobs-report-economy-analysis.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epoints out\u003c/a\u003e, the biggest job losses (498,000) were in the leisure and hospitality industries, the sectors most affected by winter lockdowns and the ones most likely to regain jobs once warmer weather/the vaccine hits. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOther industries less sensitive to Covid, such as manufacturing and construction, continued to chug along and add jobs last month. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eComing into 2020, the job market was the hottest it had ever been. There’s reason to think we could return to those heights once the virus has been vanquished.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/8/22220426/quibi-roku-channel-acquisition-content?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nHEALTH \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBiden Calls an Audible on Vaccine Rollout\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePresident-elect Joe Biden’s transition team said it \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/08/politics/biden-vaccine-strategy/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eplans to release\u003c/a\u003e almost all Covid-19 vaccine doses available in order to inject a little hare into what has been a tortoise-y immunization campaign. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e...We didn’t do that already? \u003c/strong\u003eNope. Since both of the vaccines approved by the FDA require \u003cem\u003etwo\u003c/em\u003e doses spaced a few weeks apart, the current administration has been holding back doses to ensure there’s plenty of supply to jab people a second time—and right on schedule.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMany medical experts support the current approach, arguing it’s dangerous to mess with the planned vaccine rollout. After all, what if second doses aren’t available when they’re needed?  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOthers, including former FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ScottGottliebMD/status/1347570040552435714?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadvocate\u003c/a\u003e prioritizing the first dose in a campaign informally called “First Doses First” (FDF). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2021/01/first-doses-first-and-herd-immunity.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThe simplest argument\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in favor of FDF, writes economist Alex Tabarrok, is that “two vaccinated people confers more immunity than one double vaccinated person.”  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eBiden’s betting that a) we can give more people first shots \u003cem\u003enow\u003c/em\u003e, and while that happens b) manufacturers can ramp up production to provide enough second doses when they’re needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs we leave 2020 in the rearview mirror, many sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eA look at the new faces\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eKia: \u003c/strong\u003eIn the most extra logo launch of 2021, Kia debuted its updated look using \u003ca href=\"https://youtu.be/s61_IsjqLzc?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e303 pyrodrones\u003c/a\u003e and a massive fireworks display over South Korea. Early reviews are not great, Bob. MotorTrend wrote that it “resembles a futuristic inkblot test,” and we’re inclined to agree. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGM:\u003c/strong\u003e In another vehicular facelift, GM \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-08/gm-changes-corporate-logo-to-plug-its-electric-vehicle-strategy?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echanged its corporate logo\u003c/a\u003e for the first time in 56 years yesterday to highlight its electric vehicle strategy. How does the new logo do that, exactly? If you look closely, the lowercase “m” is supposed to resemble an electric plug. Key words: supposed to. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCIA:\u003c/strong\u003e The Central Intelligence Agency’s full brand redesign is definitely the most controversial of the trio. “If I didn’t read the copy, I wouldn’t know if this was for a direct-to-consumer designer toothbrush or an organization that’s been accused of destabilizing governments worldwide,” freelance Creative Director Eric Hu \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/08/style/cia-rebrand.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold\u003c/a\u003e the NYT. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Marketing Brew writer Phoebe Bain points out there is a method to the madness. “Lots of brands are opting for brighter and flatter logos in a
